Infine, lungo la Costa delle Spezie, gli spinosauri trasportano carichi di spezie di alto valore lungo la costa quando il banditismo è diffuso o quando una compagnia di mercenari lizardfolk è disponibile per sorvegliare i materiali diretti a nord verso Mhalmet, Nuria o Ishadia. Queste bestie della Costa delle Spezie sono spesso allevate per ottenere colorazioni sgargianti: linee di sangue verdi e arancioni, blu e oro e persino rosse e nere sono state avvistate nei porti della Costa delle Spezie.

trait.name: Chill of the Void
entries: I danni da freddo inflitti dal drago del vuoto ignorano la resistenza ai danni da freddo, ma non l'immunità al freddo.

trait.name: Void Dweller
entries: I draghi del vuoto vivono nella distesa vuota tra le stelle e non hanno bisogno di aria, cibo, bevande o sonno. Quando vola tra le stelle, il drago del vuoto scivola magicamente sui venti solari, compiendo l'immenso viaggio attraverso il vuoto in un tempo incredibilmente breve.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} per colpire, portata 5 ft., un bersaglio. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) danni da taglio.

action.name: Breath Weapons {@recharge 5}
entries: Il drago utilizza una delle seguenti armi a soffio.

items.name: Gravitic Breath
items.entry: The dragon exhales a 30-foot cube of powerful localized gravity, originating from the dragon. Falling damage in the area increases to {@dice 1d10} per 10 feet fallen. When a creature starts its turn within the area or enters it for the first time in a turn, including when the dragon creates the field, it must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure the creature is {@condition restrained}. On a success the creature's speed is halved as long as it remains in the field. A {@condition restrained} creature repeats the saving throw at the end of its turn. The field persists until the dragon's breath recharges, and it can't use gravitic breath twice consecutively.

items.name: Stellar Flare Breath
items.entry: The dragon exhales star fire in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw, taking 28 ({@damage 8d6}) fire damage and 28 ({@damage 8d6}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

reaction.name: Void Twist
entries: When the dragon is hit by a ranged attack it can create a small rift in space to increase its AC by 4 against that attack. If the attack misses because of this increase the dragon can choose a creature within 30 feet to become the new target for that attack. Use the original attack roll to determine if the attack hits the new target.
{@i A dragon seemingly formed of the night sky has bright white stars for eyes. Lesser stars twinkle in the firmament of the dragon's body.}

entries.name: Children of the Stars
entries: I draghi del Vuoto vagano negli spazi vuoti oltre i confini del mondo mortale, vagando tra le stelle. Sono distaccati e si mescolano solo con gli esseri ultraterreni che vivono sopra e oltre la terra, comprese le forme incarnate delle stelle stesse. Quando le creature minori visitano i draghi del vuoto, i draghi stessi se ne accorgono appena.

entries.name: Witnesses to the Void
entries: I draghi del Vuoto sono creature estremamente consapevoli, ma hanno visto troppo, indugiando ai margini del Vuoto stesso. Guardare il nulla che sbadiglia all'esterno ha richiesto un tributo. I draghi del vuoto portano con sé un pezzo di quel nulla, che lentamente divora il loro essere. Sono tutti impazziti e la loro follia è contagiosa. Quando i draghi si infuriano e si scatenano, la loro follia è contagiosa e si riversa sulle menti degli esseri inferiori.

entries.name: Voracious Scholars
entries: Nonostante la loro esistenza rimossa e le loro stranezze, i draghi del vuoto accumulano ancora tesori. Le gemme che brillano come le stelle della loro casa sono particolarmente apprezzate. Il loro pezzo forte, tuttavia, è la conoscenza. I draghi del Vuoto conservano gelosamente frammenti di storia proibita e dimenticata di qualsiasi tipo e passano la maggior parte del tempo a casa a studiare questi tesori. Guai a chi disturba questa collezione, perché niente accende la loro follia latente come una violazione del loro tesoro.

entries.name: Void Dragons in Midgard
entries: I draghi del Vuoto sono i figli maggiori di Veles, il Serpente del Mondo, e sono venerati come divini dai suoi seguaci. Alcune storie affermano che furono i primi a insegnare la magia agli elfi.

entries.name: A Void Dragon's Lair
entries: La vera tana di un drago del vuoto esiste nelle profondità del vuoto gelido e senza aria tra le stelle. Nascosta in caverne su asteroidi alla deriva o scintillante in cima alle rovine di una Cittadella Stellare, la tana del drago del vuoto si trova nel grande vuoto dello spazio.

Quando un drago del vuoto reclama una casa altrove, crea un legame con la sua vera tana. Preferisce le cime delle montagne, le valli o le rovine ad alta quota con una chiara visione del cielo. Da questa tana può attraversare lo spazio per raggiungere il suo tesoro nascosto nel vuoto. Questa connessione ha ovviamente delle ripercussioni e i draghi del vuoto più potenti lasciano il loro segno sul mondo circostante quando si appollaiano. Intrusioni dall'aldilà e sete di conoscenza proibita sono comuni nei pressi delle loro tane.
Se combattuto nella sua tana, la sua Sfida aumenta di 1, fino a 15 per un adulto (13.000 XP) e 25 per un antico drago del vuoto (75.000 XP).

trait.name: Fog Vision
entries: Il drago vede normalmente attraverso oscuramenti leggeri o pesanti causati da nebbia, foschia, nuvole o vento forte.

trait.name: Uncontrollable
entries: Il movimento del drago non è mai ostacolato da terreni difficili e la sua velocità non può essere ridotta da incantesimi o effetti magici. Non può essere {@condition restrained} (secondo la condizione) e sfugge automaticamente a qualsiasi vincolo non magico (come catene, impigli o prese) spendendo 5 piedi di movimento. Essere sott'acqua non impone alcuna penalità al movimento o agli attacchi.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} per colpire, portata 5 ft., un bersaglio. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) danni da taglio.

action.name: Breath of Gales {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon exhales a blast of wind in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that cone takes 11 ({@damage 2d10}) bludgeoning damage and is pushed 25 feet away from the dragon and knocked {@condition prone}; a successful {@dc 16} Strength saving throw halves the damage and prevents being pushed and knocked {@condition prone}. Unprotected flames in the cone are extinguished, and sheltered flames (such as those in lanterns) have a {@chance 75} chance of being extinguished.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The dragon's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}). It can innately cast the following spell, requiring no material components:

entries: {@i Howling wind encircles the white- and gray-scaled dragon, filling and pushing its wings without the need for them to beat.}

I draghi del vento considerano di loro proprietà qualsiasi luogo toccato dall'aria e i mortali li considerano l'epitome dell'arroganza. Il loro narcisismo non è privo di ragione, poiché un potere impressionante sostiene le loro pretese di controllo. Per i draghi dei venti mutevoli, la forza è l'arbitro finale. Sebbene i wyrming dei draghi del vento siano i più deboli tra i draghi neonati, il loro potere cresce rapidamente e pochi draghi adulti sono considerati più forti.

entries.name: Braggarts and Bullies
entries: I draghi del vento sono tra i più prepotenti e i peggiori tiranni tra le creature mortali. Queste creature, talvolta avventate, si offendono personalmente per qualsiasi sfida percepita e provano grande piacere nell'umiliare i rivali. Rivendicano grandi estensioni di territorio, ma si preoccupano poco del suo governo e considerano i mortali che vi abitano come dei possedimenti. I vassalli ricevono solo una dubbia protezione in cambio di una fedeltà incrollabile. Un drago del vento potrebbe cercare una vendetta sanguinosa per l'omicidio di un seguace, ma è improbabile che faccia di tutto per evitare la perdita di vite umane.

entries.name: Lords of the Far Horizons
entries: Alcuni ritengono che i draghi dei venti pretendano molto più di quanto siano in grado di controllare o pattugliare. Poiché amano l'altitudine, preferiscono governare e incontrare i supplicanti terrestri nel punto più alto disponibile: la cima di una grande montagna o in cima a un imponente monumento eretto da schiavi timorosi. Ma questi draghi sono anche spinti dalla voglia di vagabondare e spesso viaggiano lontano dai loro troni. Alla fine tornano sempre, pronti a soggiogare nuove generazioni e a premere un artiglio tirannico sul collo di chiunque metta in discussione il loro diritto di governare.

entries.name: Perpetual Infighting
entries: Questi tiranni erranti sono ancora più territoriali tra i loro simili che tra i terrestri. Il semplice sconfinamento di un drago del vento nel territorio di un altro può portare a una battaglia all'ultimo sangue. Per questo il loro numero non cresce mai e i più deboli vengono spesso eliminati.

I tesori dei draghi del vento consistono in genere solo in poche reliquie di valore. Altri draghi potrebbero dormire su un letto di monete, ma le cose comuni annoiano rapidamente i draghi del vento. Mentre tutti i veri draghi desiderano e ostentano grandi ricchezze, i draghi del vento concentrano le loro ricchezze in un numero ridotto di trofei notevoli o di oggetti storici unici, spesso piuttosto portatili.

entries.name: Wind Dragon Tactics
entries: I draghi del vento preferiscono combattere dall'aria e possono essere efficaci con incantesimi e armi a soffio. Tuttavia, ciò può essere piuttosto frustrante per i gruppi che non dispongono di attacchi a distanza; anche in questo caso, i draghi antichi sono immuni agli attacchi a distanza non magici e i draghi del vento adulti impongono uno svantaggio. Inoltre, le azioni leggendarie del drago del vento e il suo attacco multiplo richiedono di essere più vicini e in mischia. I draghi del vento sono progettati per ammorbidire i nemici a distanza e poi piombare per uccidere in mischia, portando via una o più vittime.

entries.name: Wind Dragon's Lair
entries: I draghi del vento costruiscono le loro tane in luoghi in cui possono dominare la terra che rivendicano come propria, ma abbastanza remoti da impedire agli abitanti di assillarli con richieste di protezione o giustizia. Non hanno molto da temere dagli elementi, quindi l'ideale è una grotta poco profonda in cima a una parete montuosa esposta. I draghi del vento amano le alture punteggiate di guglie rocciose e le alte pareti rocciose a strapiombo, dove il drago può appollaiarsi nel vento ululante e catturare le correnti ascensionali e discensionali che spazzano i canyon e attraversano i dirupi. Le creature non volanti trovano questi luoghi molto meno ospitali.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} +3to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d8 + 1}) piercing damage, and the target must make a successful {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned}. While {@condition poisoned} this way, the target is blind and takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage at the start of each of its turns. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself with a success.
{@i Greenish liquid drips from the dagger-length fangs of this 20-foot-long monstrosity. They show little fear.}

entries.name: Human Hunters
entries: This giant venomous snake is known as one of the most lethal serpents, and one of the few that will attack an adult human. One bite from the Zanskaran viper can kill a healthy human in seconds, and its tough hide makes it difficult to dispatch quickly.

entries.name: Jungle Bred
entries: A Zanskaran viper grows quickly in its jungle home, and some even venture into the savannah to terrorize antelopes and young giraffes. A full-grown Zanskaran viper is up to 30 feet long and weighs up to 400 pounds.

entries.name: Famous but Rare Venom
entries: A dose of its viscous green venom is known to fetch as much as 2,500 gp on the black market, but it is rarely available.

trait.name: Fortified Shell
entries: The zaratan ignores any attack against its shell that doesn't do 30 points of damage or more. Attacking the zaratan's head or flippers bypasses this trait.

trait.name: Endless Breath
entries: The zaratan breathes air, but it can hold its breath for years.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the zaratan remains motionless on the surface of the ocean (except for drifting) it is indistinguishable from a small island.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The zaratan does double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The zaratan makes one bite attack and two flipper attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 18} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 3d10 + 10}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 20}). Until the grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained} and the zaratan can't bite another target.

action.name: Flipper
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 18} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 2d8 + 10}) bludgeoning damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 26} Strength saving throw or be pushed 10 feet away from the zaratan.

action.name: Swallow
entries: The zaratan makes one bite attack against a Huge or smaller creature it is grappling. If the attack hits, the target takes 26 ({@damage 3d10 + 10}) piercing damage, is swallowed, and the grapple ends. A swallowed creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, but has total cover against attacks and effects outside the zaratan. A swallowed creature takes 28 ({@damage 8d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the zaratan's turns. The zaratan can have any number of creatures swallowed at once. If the zaratan takes 40 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the zaratan must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the zaratan. If the zaratan dies, swallowed creatures are no longer {@condition restrained} and can escape by using 30 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The zaratan moves up to half its speed.

legendary.name: Swipe
entries: The zaratan makes one flipper attack.

legendary.name: Consume (2 actions)
entries: The zaratan makes one bite attack or uses Swallow.
{@i One of the rocks suddenly lurches, and rises out of the water. A great eye glides open in the side of what seemed to be a boulder, and a massive, beaklike mouth gapes in the surf.}

entries.name: Island Reefs
entries: The zaratan is an impossibly huge sea turtle so large that entire ecosystems develop and grow on its stony, mountainous shell. Drifting on warm ocean currents or settled on shoals, they are often mistaken for small tropical islands. The creature's head is at least 100 feet in diameter, with a ridge in the center like a tall hill. Its head resembles a massive boulder, and its 200-foot long flippers are mistaken for reefs.

entries.name: Ageless Slumber
entries: Zaratans spend their millennia-long lives in slumber. They drift on the surface of the ocean, their mouths slightly open, and reflexively swallow larger creatures that explore the "cave." They spend centuries at a time asleep. A zaratan may know secrets long lost to the world, if only it can be awakened and bargained with.

entries.name: Deep Divers
entries: Waking a zaratan is a dangerous proposition, as their usual response to any injury severe enough to waken them is to dive to the crushing black depths. Some zaratan commune with oceanic races in this time, such as deep ones, sahuagin, or aboleth.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The zimwi makes one claws attack and one bite attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature {@condition grappled} by the zimwi, that creature is swallowed, and the grapple ends. While swallowed, the creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the zimwi, and it takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the zimwi's turns. If the zimwi's stomach takes 20 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the zimwi must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 5 feet of the zimwi. Damage done to a zimwi's stomach does not harm the zimwi. The zimwi's stomach is larger on the inside than the outside. It can have two Medium creatures or four Small or smaller creatures swallowed at one time. If the zimwi dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse using 5 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage, and if the target is a Medium or smaller creature and the zimwi isn't already grappling a creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 11}).
{@i This swift-moving, lanky humanoid has long arms ending in wicked claws and jaws that open impossibly wide.}

entries.name: Swift as Horses
entries: Distantly related to the trolls, the swift and nimble zimwi are a plague upon southern lands. Constantly hungry and ill-tempered, with the speed to run down horses, lone zimwi have been known to attack large caravans.

entries.name: Always Starving
entries: Most of their attacks are driven by hunger. The stomach of a zimwi is larger than its body, extending extra-dimensionally and driving the zimwi nearly insane with the constant sensation of emptiness, as though it is starving to death. Because of their endless hunger and low intelligence, zimwi have little awareness of the course of a battle. Losing means only that they have not eaten. As long as they continue to feast, they fight on, feeling victorious until death comes to them or all of their prey.

entries.name: Stomachs of Holding
entries: The mage-crafters discovered the secret to turning zimwi stomachs into extradimensional containers similar to {@item bag of holding|DMG|bags of holdings}. Using a zimwi stomach in the creation of such items reduces the cost of materials by half.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The zmey can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Lake Leap
entries: A zmey spends much of its time lurking in lakes and ponds. When submerged in a natural pool of standing water, it can transport itself as a bonus action to a similar body of water within 5,000 feet. Rapidly flowing water doesn't serve for this ability, but the zmey can leap to or from a river or stream where the water is calm and slow-moving.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day)
entries: If the zmey fails a saving throw, it can count it as a success instead.

trait.name: Multiheaded
entries: The zmey normally has three heads. While it has more than one head, the zmey has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, and {@condition stunned}. If the zmey takes 40 or more damage in a single turn (and the damage isn't poison or psychic), one of its heads is severed. If all three of its heads are severed, the zmey dies.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The zmey regains 15 hit points at the start of its turn. If the zmey takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the zmey's next turn. Regeneration stops functioning when all heads are severed. It takes 24 hours for a zmey to regrow a functional head.

trait.name: Spawn Headling
entries: The severed head of a zmey grows into a zmey headling {@dice 2d6} rounds after being separated from the body. Smearing at least a pound of salt on the severed head's stump prevents this transformation.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The zmey makes one bite attack per head and one claws attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 2d12 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 2d12 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Fire Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The zmey breathes up to three 60-foot cones of fire, one from each of its heads. Creatures in a cone take 16 ({@damage 3d10}) fire damage, or half damage with a successful {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw. If cones overlap, their damage adds together but each target makes only one saving throw. A zmey can choose whether this attack harms plants or plant creatures.

legendary.name: Bite
entries: The zmey makes a bite attack.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: The zmey makes a tail attack.

legendary.name: Trample
entries: The zmey moves up to half its land speed. It can enter enemy-occupied spaces but can't end its move there. Creatures in spaces the zmey enters must make successful {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throws or take 10 ({@damage 1d8 + 6}) bludgeoning damage and fall {@condition prone}.

{@i Crashing through the forest, this three-headed dragon stands upright, its spiked tail thrashing from side to side as it walks. A vicious mouth lined with glistening teeth graces each head, and its green scales gleam in the fleeting sunlight.}
Hunting beneath the canopy of the forest, lurking below the surfaces of lakes, and guarding caves concealing great treasure and mystery, the zmey has two roles—vicious terror and nature's protector.

entries.name: Claws of the Forest
entries: Single-mindedly destructive, the zmey keeps the heart of the forest free from interlopers. Rumors suggest the heart of an ancient forest itself can control the actions of these beasts, while others believe that they have a pact with certain forest druids. Certainly they are clever enough, often destroying bridges, dams, or logging camps infringing on their territory.

entries.name: Solitary Hunters
entries: Zmey avoid their own kind, seeking out isolated hunting grounds. They eat any organic matter, but they favor the fresh meat of large birds and mammals. The smarter the prey, the better, because zmey believe that intellect flavors the meat. They consider alseids, halflings, and gnomes especially succulent.

entries.name: Three-Headed Rage
entries: Dappled black and green scales cover this enormous beast and its three towering necks are long and powerful. Each neck is topped with an identical, menacing head, and each head is flanked by spiny, frilled membranes. A forked tongue flickers across long pale teeth, and six pairs of eyes burn red with rage.
When a zmey stands upright, it measures 25 feet from snout to tail. The beast weighs over 9,000 lb.

entries.name: Zmey Headling
entries: A zmey's head doesn't die when severed from the body. Instead, the head rapidly (within {@dice 2d6} rounds) sprouts a {@creature Zmey Headling|ToB|stunted body} and two vestigial claws with which it can fight and drag itself across the ground. Within days it develops into a complete, miniature zmey, and by the time two lunar cycles elapse, the head regenerates into a full-grown zmey with three heads.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The zmey headling can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The zmey headling reaver regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. This trait doesn't function if the zmey headling took acid or fire damage since the end of its previous turn. It dies if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The zmey headling makes one claw attack and one bite attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d12 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Fire Breath {@recharge}
entries: The zmey headling exhales fire in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area takes 16 ({@damage 3d10}) fire damage, or half damage with a successful {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw.

{@i Crashing through the forest, this three-headed dragon stands upright, its spiked tail thrashing from side to side as it walks. A vicious mouth lined with glistening teeth graces each head, and its green scales gleam in the fleeting sunlight.}
Hunting beneath the canopy of the forest, lurking below the surfaces of lakes, and guarding caves concealing great treasure and mystery, the zmey has two roles—vicious terror and nature's protector.

entries.name: Claws of the Forest
entries: Single-mindedly destructive, the zmey keeps the heart of the forest free from interlopers. Rumors suggest the heart of an ancient forest itself can control the actions of these beasts, while others believe that they have a pact with certain forest druids. Certainly they are clever enough, often destroying bridges, dams, or logging camps infringing on their territory.

entries.name: Solitary Hunters
entries: Zmey avoid their own kind, seeking out isolated hunting grounds. They eat any organic matter, but they favor the fresh meat of large birds and mammals. The smarter the prey, the better, because zmey believe that intellect flavors the meat. They consider alseids, halflings, and gnomes especially succulent.

entries.name: Three-Headed Rage
entries: Dappled black and green scales cover this enormous beast and its three towering necks are long and powerful. Each neck is topped with an identical, menacing head, and each head is flanked by spiny, frilled membranes. A forked tongue flickers across long pale teeth, and six pairs of eyes burn red with rage.
When a zmey stands upright, it measures 25 feet from snout to tail. The beast weighs over 9,000 lb.

entries.name: Zmey Headling
entries: A zmey's head doesn't die when severed from the body. Instead, the head rapidly (within {@dice 2d6} rounds) sprouts a stunted body and two vestigial claws with which it can fight and drag itself across the ground. Within days it develops into a complete, miniature zmey, and by the time two lunar cycles elapse, the head regenerates into a full-grown zmey with three heads.

disease.name: Darakhul Fever
entries: Spread mainly through bite wounds, this rare disease makes itself known within 24 hours by swiftly debilitating the infected. A creature so afflicted must make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw after every long rest. Failure costs the victim {@dice 1d6} Constitution damage and {@dice 1d4} Dexterity damage. The victim recovers from the disease by making successful saving throws on two consecutive days, but the accumulating Constitution damage makes this less likely with each passing day. {@spell Greater restoration} cures the disease; {@spell cure disease} allows the victim to make the daily Constitution check with advantage. Once the disease is cured, the victim recovers 2 Dexterity points per day naturally, but only magic can restore the lost Constitution.
Primarily spread among humanoids, the disease can affect ogres, and therefore other giants may be susceptible.

If the infected creature dies while infected with darakhul fever, roll {@dice d20}, add the character's current Constitution modifier, and find the result on the Adjustment Table to determine what undead form the victim's body rises in.

disease.name: Arcane Wasting
entries: An outbreak of arcane wasting is always met with horror, but that fear is felt tenfold by practitioners of magic both arcane and divine.

When the bodily fluid of an infected creature touches a humanoid or when an infected creature casts a spell (direct or indirect) on a humanoid, that humanoid must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become infected with arcane wasting. Beginning {@dice 1d6} days after infection, the infected creature must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw at the end of each long rest. If the saving throw fails, the victim loses {@dice 1d3} Intelligence and {@dice 1d3} Wisdom. Lost Intelligence and Wisdom can't be recovered while the disease persists. If the saving throw succeeds, nothing happens; the disease ends after the second consecutive successful saving throws. Once the disease ends, lost Intelligence and Wisdom can be restored by {@spell greater restoration} or comparable magic. The disease is also cured by {@spell lesser restoration} if the caster makes a successful {@dc 15} spellcasting check.

item.name: Wyrmblood Venom
entries: Bone collectives create a reddish liquid, which they smear on their fangs. The freakish red mouths on the tiny skeletons are disturbing, and the toxin is deadly. A bitten creature must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} and take {@dice 1d6} Charisma damage. A {@condition poisoned} creature repeats the saving throw every four hours, taking another {@dice 1d6} Charisma damage for each failure, until it has made two consecutive successful saves or survived for 24 hours. If the creature survives, the effect ends and the creature can heal normally. Lost Charisma can be regained with a {@spell lesser restoration} spell or comparable magic.

optionalfeature.name: Ethereal Jaunt
entries: As a bonus action, the creature can magically shift from the Material Plane to the Ethereal Plane, or vice versa.

{@note This is referenced as a spell in various statblocks in Tome of Beasts. While the text is only presented in full on one statblock, we assume the feature works the same for other creatures (in addition, this matches the feature with the same name found in official Wizards of the Coast sourcebooks).}

language.name: Void Speech
entries: Il Linguaggio del Vuoto è la lingua delle creature dell'Oscurità Esterna nell'Ambientazione della Campagna di Midgard, parlata da cose vili e malevole nei confronti degli umani e dei loro alleati, che cercano di provocare la rovinosa apocalisse degli dei oscuri. Se si utilizza un'altra ambientazione, si può sostituire con una qualsiasi lingua antica con una reputazione malvagia.

magicvariant.name: Cold Iron Weapon
entries: I signori e le signore delle corti fey sono creature senza tempo, abituate a molte delle minacce del mondo. Un'eccezione universale è rappresentata dalle armi di ferro battuto a freddo. Questo metallo disfa il tessuto stesso della vita di una creatura fey, poiché ne intacca la carne senza età. Un'arma di ferro freddo è considerata magica quando viene usata contro qualsiasi creatura fey ed è l'unica arma che ha qualche speranza di danneggiare i signori e le signore fey più potenti.

Le armi di ferro freddo, tuttavia, sono difficili da costruire. L'abilità e i materiali necessari per produrre un'arma di questo tipo raddoppiano il suo prezzo o aggiungono 100 gp al costo, a seconda di quale sia il più alto. Trovare un fabbro con l'abilità di fabbricare un'arma durevole senza l'ausilio del fuoco è sempre difficile, e trovarne uno con il coraggio di far arrabbiare le corti feudali può essere ancora più difficile.
A cold iron weapon is treated as magical when used against any fey creature.
